commit.title: [rfc] [build] Preliminary support for building with `dune`.
commit.message:
[rfc] [build] Preliminary support for building with `dune`.

[Dune](https://github.com/ocaml/dune) is a compositional declarative
build system for OCaml. It provides several advantages such as
automatic generation of `version.ml`, `.merlin`, `META`, `opam`, API
documentation, install management, easy integration with external
libraries, test runners, and modular builds.

In particular, Dune uniformly handles components regardless if they
live in or out-of-tree. This greatly simplifies cases where a plugin
[or CoqIde] is check out in the current working copy but then
distributed separately [and vice-versa]. Dune can be, thus, used as a
more flexible `coq_makefile` replacement.

To build Coq with Dune type:
```
bash jb.sh
```

=== Implementation summary:

In Dune, each directory corresponds to a _library_; thus, we provide a
`jbuild` library specification for each Coq source component. Dune
doesn't support custom rules, thus we provide a small helper script
`tools/gen_libbuild.ml` that will scan the codebase and generate the
corresponding rules for `.v -> .vo` and `.ml4 -> .ml` builds. The
script depends on `coqdep` as to correctly output the dependencies of
`.v` files.

Dune doesn't support dynamic rules, thus the build process goes as: 1)
build `coqdep` with Dune; 2) generate `jbuild` files for `theories`
and `plugins`; 3) all targets in scope, regular build.

=== Status / TODO

The current PR provides support for building the full Coq distribution
with Dune, while keeping the current, make-based build system as a
separate option.

The patch depends on some minor changes to the codebase, mainly to
adapt Coq's source code to Dune-specific module-packing method
structure and to avoid spurious dependencies.

The main TODO is to perform some refinement and cleanup on some common
parts such as configure or `coqdep`. An itemized TODO:

- Improve `configure` to better support `dune`, avoid soft link hacks,
  implement silent mode for auto-conf.
- Update / wait for dune new features
- Better toplevel search path technology.
- Tweak `Coq_config`, avoid so many dependencies.
- Install target.
- Doc target.
- OPAM / META generation.

== FAQ:

=== Why Dune?

Coq has a moderately complex build system and it is not a secret that
many developer-hours have been spent fighting with `make`.

In particular, the current `make`-based system does offer poor support
to verify that the current build rules and variables are coherent, and
requires significant manual, error-prone. Many variables must be
passed by hand, duplicated, etc... Additionally, our make system
offers poor integration with now standard OCaml ecosystem tools such
as OPAM, `ocamlfind` or odoc. Another critical point is build
compositionality. Coq is rich in 3rd party contributions, and a big
shortcoming of the current make system is that it cannot be used to
build these projects; requiring us to maintain a custom tool,
`coq_makefile`, with the corresponding cost.

In the past, there are been some efforts to migrate Coq to more
specialized build systems, however these stalled due to a variety of
reasons. Dune, is a declarative OCaml-specific build tool that has the
potential to become the standard build system of the OCaml ecosystem.

Dune seems to address the needs of Coq has: well-supported, fast, and
designed for large projects.

=== What's new with Dune?

- utop
- install
- easy packing => for example errors => cerrors
- uses a better method than timestamps to detect dependencies
- it avoids breaking of modularization by spurious forward references
  as we do [often] today.
- coqp5, a native-code customized camlp5 executable which brings much
  faster ml4->ml processing.

=== Does Dune replace the `make`-based build system?

For the moment the plan is for both systems to coexists. Dune uses a
separate build directory `_build` and doesn't interfere with the old
in-tree build.

=== What dependencies does Dune require?

Dune doesn't depend on any 3rd party package other than the OCaml compiler.

=== Does Dune replace `coq_makefile`?

Dune can indeed be used to replace `coq_makefile`. See an example [here]().

=== Why all the `.mli-> .ml` changes?

`.mli`-only modules, "without implementation", are not properly
supported by the OCaml compiler. In particular, they cannot be
aliased/placed into a pack, which is a problem for large projects such
as Coq.

=== Bugs fixed [not marking them yet to avoid Github spam]:

- 4857

=== Benchmarks [not yet oranges-to-oranges but almost]:

- `jbuild`:
  real	0m30,518s
  user	0m49,209s
  sys	0m10,937s

- `make -j 4 bin/coqtop`:
  real	0m32,282s
  user	0m59,981s
  sys	0m14,499s

=== Test battery

- Check that `Drop.` works.
- Check coqide + workers
- Check that compilation works.

`jbuild` library specification for each Coq source component. Dune
doesn't support custom rules, thus we provide a small helper script
`tools/gen_libbuild.ml` that will scan the codebase and generate the

to verify that the current build rules and variables are coherent, and
requires significant manual, error-prone. Many variables must be
passed by hand, duplicated, etc... Additionally, our make system
offers poor integration with now standard OCaml ecosystem tools such
as OPAM, `ocamlfind` or odoc. Another critical point is build
compositionality. Coq is rich in 3rd party contributions, and a big
shortcoming of the current make system is that it cannot be used to
build these projects; requiring us to maintain a custom tool,
`coq_makefile`, with the corresponding cost.

specialized build systems, however these stalled due to a variety of
reasons. Dune, is a declarative OCaml-specific build tool that has the
potential to become the standard build system of the OCaml ecosystem.

- install

  as we do [often] today.
